Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploring the Influence of an Asset-Focused Intervention on Students' Interest, Motivation, and Sense of Belonging in the Life Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This intervention will explore whether technology enhanced professional development will provide third and fifth grade science teachers with the knowledge and skills needed to prepare and inspire students to become more interested and motivated to pursue careers in STEM fields. The professional development will provide teachers with instructional strategies that promote students' relational mattering and sense of belonging that will help retain students in the STEM pipeline. The project will target low-income African-American students from three high need schools in Washington, DC, through engagement in life science lessons with the ultimate goal of increasing students' awareness and interest in STEM. This intervention will offer continuous professional development to promote teachers' use of asset-focused instructional strategies that take into account students' cultural practices, values, and lived experiences evident in the children's home or community environments. Professional development will be offered through face-to-face summer and academic year professional development academies and the Torsh TALENT technology online platform. Both pathways feature ongoing review of instructional and student learning practices, immediate feedback between trainers and teachers, more opportunities for teachers to view and reflect on their craft, and space for virtual life science communal exchange across participating schools. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

A mixed methods research design will be used to collect focus group and survey data, as well as conduct classroom observations, to determine if the foreground variables of students' relational mattering, sense of belonging, and engagement are interrelated. Research literature has shown that students' engagement in the learning process is an important predictor of ultimate academic performance outcomes. It is anticipated that the students' socioemotional perceptions should positively relate not only to each other but to student engagement levels as well; hence helping to confirm the academic relevance of such socioemotional considerations. The Student Socioemotional Perception Tool will be modified to assess students' perception changes given their teachers' participation in the professional development intervention. The study of these social emotional factors with elementary age African-American students in high needs school settings has the potential to advance the knowledge of largely unexplored conceptual directions in need of systematic empirical scrutiny. The Talent Quest Model, based on the human capacity framework, is actualized in how teachers elicit and use student assets with regard to lessons, learning activities, and life science subject matter inside classrooms on an everyday basis. Hence, a major outcome will be modifying a developmentally appropriate measurement tool to gauge elementary level students' perspectives on their relational mattering and sense of belonging during life science lessons beyond its early development and pilot stage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supporting teachers in the process of engaging their students in life science content and keeping them in the STEM pipeline is imperative. This is especially true if it is widely accepted that our nation needs to produce viable work and progress in the global STEM realm. To address this concern, it will require a STEM-educated workforce to meet the demands of an increasingly technology-driven economy and society. Moreover, much of that workforce must be taken from the growing ethnic minority populations, hence we must produce greater numbers of minority group scientists and engineers (US Commission on Civil Rights, 2010). One fundamental path to peaking student interest in science is through supporting their teachers in providing the right learning structures and activities in science classrooms. Young children are natural observers of their surroundings and are fascinated by even the most common of living things, especially when they are encouraged to look at life in ways that scientists do, to ask their own questions, and to shape their own answers. The key for teachers is to build on students' existing knowledge and enthusiasm of the natural world to help them understand and use scientific knowledge. The best investigation topics, like those in life sciences, are ones that children encounter on a daily basis and that allow for hands-on inquiry (Annenberg Foundation, 2004; Bosse, Jacobs, & Anderson, 2009). It is in this vein that this intervention provided technology-enhanced professional development support to teachers that highlights ways they can elicit students' assets and competencies in life science classrooms. Specifically, the intervention targeted 3rd through 5th grade science teachers in high needs schools with a large population of African-American students. 

There were several cutting-edge, potentially transformative but largely untested considerations that were explored via this intervention that can add to and advance the knowledge and understanding of the best ways to increase underrepresented students' engagement, awareness and interest in STEM-related content, especially in life science. For example, we explored teachers' transfer and implementation of asset-focused strategies to their life science instruction; student engagement levels during science instruction; students sense of mattering and belonging; students STEM interest and awareness, and STEM knowledge. 

Trained observers rated the instructional practices of teachers and student engagement levels of students in the 3rd-5thgrade science classrooms using Capstone's multidimensional observation checklist. Students of the 3rd-5th grade science teachers also completed a self-report survey that examined their perceptions of relational mattering, sense of belonging, STEM interest and awareness, and STEM knowledge.

The data from the project has yielded promising results. Based on the teacher observation data, 3rd-5th grade science teachers across the three partnering schools demonstrated growth from the needs assessment observation (pretest) to end of year observation (posttest), with every instructional practice being rated above the "Does It Well/Often" threshold.

Similarly, at each sampling period, student engagement levels during science instruction were between the "Adequate/Sufficient" and "Great Deal/High Engagement" markers and rose significantly at the .001 level from pretest to posttest observations.

Additionally, based on the student self-report data, students, on average, believed they mattered to their teachers, felt a sense of belongingness to the overall learning environment, showed interest in and awareness of STEM concepts and principles, and demonstrated STEM knowledge growth from pretest to posttest. Students' perceptions of relational mattering and belonging increased from pretest to posttest, as well. Further, students displays of accurate STEM knowledge also rose from pretest to posttest.

Relational Mattering was found to be positively correlated with students Sense of Belonging (r = .822), STEM Interest and Awareness (r = .817), and STEM Knowledge (r = .756). Thus, as students' perceptions of relational mattering increased, their sense of belonging, interest and awareness of STEM, and knowledge of STEM-focused content increased as well. Additionally, Sense of Belonging was also positively correlated with STEM Interest and Awareness (r = .830), meaning that the more students felt connected to their learning environment, the more interested and aware of STEM concepts and principles they were. All correlations were significant at the .05 level or below.

The intellectual merit of the intervention is inherent in the statistically significant relationships that were found between the 3rd-5th grade science teachers implementation of asset-focused instructional strategies, student engagement, students sense of mattering and belonging, and students STEM interest and awareness.  The systematic investigation of the relationship between social emotional experiences and engagement on the retention of young African-American learners from marginalized backgrounds in the STEM pipeline will expand the research and scholarship of best practices to increase STEM participation for this population. 

The broader impacts of this intervention entail expanding access to high quality evidence based training and professional development opportunities to K-12 Science Educators who serve underrepresented minority students by providing training opportunities, and advanced frameworks to undergird research and high-quality science teaching and learning.
